greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: If n even, a(n) = 6n+3, otherwise a(n) = n.
reference: Although the OEIS indexes sequences by consecutive integers, it is better to think of this sequence as defined on the odd numbers 1,3,5,7,... and given by f(4m+1)=12m+3, f(4m+3)=2m+1, that is, subtract 1 and divide by 2 if the result is odd, otherwise multiply by 3. This arises in analyzing A109732.
It is conjectured that starting with any positive odd number d and iterating f, we always eventually reach either 1, 9, or 33 (see Comments in A135730).
link: Colin Barker, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..1000
Index entries for linear recurrences with constant coefficients, signature (0,2,0,-1).
results.author: _N. J. A. Sloane_, Sep 02 2015
